Direct decomposition of NO on Ba catalysts supported on rare earth oxides Yasuyuki Doi a Masaaki Haneda a ⁎ Masakuni Ozawa b a Advanced Ceramics Research Center, Nagoya Institute of Technology, 10-6-29 Asahigaoka, Tajimi, Gifu 507-0071, Japan Advanced Ceramics Research Center, Nagoya Institute of Technology 10-6-29 Asahigaoka Tajimi Gifu 507-0071 Japan b EcoTopia Science Institute, Nagoya University, Furo-cho, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-8603, Japan EcoTopia Science Institute, Nagoya University Furo-cho, Chikusa-ku Nagoya 464-8603 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +81 572 27 9964; fax: +81 572 27 6812. Graphical abstract The catalytic performance of Ba-doped rare earth oxides prepared by a co-precipitation method for the direct decomposition of NO was investigated. Although rare earth oxide catalyzed NO decomposition reaction, their activities were significantly increased by addition of Ba. Ba-Dy2O3, Ba-Sm2O3 and Ba-Y2O3 showed relatively high catalytic activity. CO2-TPD measurements of Ba-doped rare earth oxides revealed that Ba species supported on rare earth oxides with moderate strength of basic sites, such as Dy2O3, Sm2O3 and Y2O3, can be highly dispersed on the surface of support oxide, suggesting that highly dispersed Ba species acts as catalytically active sites for NO decomposition. Although the formation of nitrite (NO2 −) species during NO decomposition reaction over Ba-Dy2O3 and Ba-La2O3 was confirmed by in situ FT-IR spectroscopy, NO-TPD measurements suggested that the formation of N2 does not occur by the decomposition of adsorbed NOx species. Isotopic transient kinetic analysis performed using 14NO and 15NO revealed that the surface reaction of adsorbed species, probably NO2 −, as an intermediate with other NOx adspecies is a key step for the formation of N2. Highly dispersed Ba species was considered to play an important role for the formation, adsorption, stabilization and subsequent reaction of NO2 − species in NO decomposition. Keywords Direct decomposition Nitrogen monoxide Supported barium catalyst Rare earth oxide 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) emitted from combustion facilities are harmful for human health and the global environment. Because NOx are thermally formed by the radical chain mechanism proposed by Zeldovich at high temperatures above 1200°C [1], the removal of NOx from high temperature exhaust gas is necessary. Catalysis plays a very important role in reducing air pollution caused by NOx. Of all the catalytic methods to remove NOx from exhaust gases, direct decomposition of NO (2NO→N2 +O2), which is a thermodynamically favorable reaction, is the most desirable but also the most challenging NOx abatement process. Therefore, the direct decomposition of NO is one of the candidate reactions for the high temperature deNOx applications. Numerous kinds of catalysts, such as supported noble metals [2–6], ion-exchanged zeolites [7–9] and metal oxides [9–11], are known to show the catalytic activity for the direct decomposition of NO. However, up to now, none has a level of activity that would enable practical application. Poisoning the catalytically active sites by oxygen as a product for NO decomposition and/or coexisting component was regarded to be one of the most probable reasons for low catalytic performance. Therefore, extensive studies have been done to design and construct the catalytically active site structure, which can effectively promote oxygen desorption [12–16]. For example, perovskite-type oxides, which possess oxygen-deficient sites in the structure, exhibit relatively high catalytic activity in the high-temperature region. The catalytic property of perovskite-type oxides can be modified by the substitution of A-site and B-sites ions to other ions such as rare earth, alkaline earth and transition metal [17–21]. Imanaka et al. [22–27] have extensively studied the catalytic performance of rare earth oxides (REOs)-based catalysts for NO decomposition, and reported that C-type cubic structure is responsible for high NO decomposition activity. They explained the importance of C-type cubic structure by the presence of many oxygen-deficient sites, which may increase the probability of NO adsorption. They also pointed out the probability of acceleration of oxygen desorption from the surface by the redox reaction of rare earth elements [25]. Catalyst design with specific structure promoting oxygen desorption would be thus one of the strategies to develop highly active NO decomposition catalysts. On the other hand, several alkaline earth oxides, which do not include oxygen-deficient sites in the lattice, such as Sr/La2O3 and Ba/MgO were reported to effectively catalyze the NO decomposition reaction by Vannice et al. [28] and Lunsford et al. [29,30]. After the reports by Vannice et al. and Lunsford et al., one of the authors has investigated the catalytic performance of supported alkaline earth metal oxides for NO decomposition and found that Y2O3 is the most effective support and Ba/Y2O3 shows the highest NO decomposition activity, which decreased in the order of Ba/Y2O3 >Sr/Y2O3 >Ca/Y2O3 >Mg/Y2O3 >Y2O3 [31]. Ishihara et al. also reported that Ba containing metal oxide catalysts such as BaMnO-based perovskite oxides [32,33], Ba/BaY2O4 [34], Ba/Y2O3 [35] and Ba3Y3.4Sc0.6O9 [36] show relatively high NO decomposition activity. The additive effect of Ba into CeO2-based mixed oxides such as CeO2-MnOx and CeO2-FeOx was also reported by Iwamoto et al. [37–42]. In addition, Tsujimoto et al. [26] studied the additive effect of BaO into C-type cubic Y2O3-ZrO2 on th NO decomposition performance, and found that Y2O3-ZrO2-BaO catalyst exhibits relatively high NO decomposition activity even in the presence of O2, H2O or CO2. However, the catalytically active sites of supported Ba catalysts and the essential role of Ba species in NO decomposition have not been clarified so far. Recently, we have investigated the catalytic performance of Ba-Y2O3 prepared by co-precipitation method for NO decomposition, and proposed the importance of the basicity of Ba/Y2O3 for NO decomposition to occur [43], suggesting that the control of surface basicity of catalyst is important to improve the catalytic performance. The REOs are known to show different surface basicity depending on the radius of rare earth cation [44]. In the present study, we have prepared Ba-doped REOs by co-precipitation method, and then measured the catalytic activity for NO decomposition. The importance of surface basic sites on support oxide and its role for NO decomposition were investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ba-doped REOs were prepared by co-precipitation using (NH4)2CO3 as a precipitation agent, with an aqueous solution of each nitrate precursor (La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Gd, Tb, Dy, Y, Ba). The precipitate thus obtained was washed with distilled water, followed by drying at 110°C and calcination at 600°C for 5h in air. The catalyst sample was finally calcined at 900°C for 5h in air. The Ba content was fixed at 8mol%. 2.2 Activity test The direct decomposition of NO was carried out in a fixed-bed continuous flow reactor. The reaction gas composed of 1000ppm NO with He as the balance gas was fed to a 0.5g catalyst that had been pre-treated in situ in a flow of He at 900°C for 8h at a rate of 30cm3 min−1 (W/F =1.0gscm−3). In some experiments, the effect of coexisting O2 was measured by mixing O2 with the reactant gas, where the concentration of O2 was changed from 0.5 to 5%. The reaction temperature was decreased from 900 to 600°C in steps of 50°C, and the steady-state catalytic activity was measured at each temperature. The effluent gas was analyzed by gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-8A) using a Molecular Sieve 5A column (for analysis of O2 and N2) and a Porapak Q column (for analysis of N2O). A chemiluminescence NOx analyzer (Shimadzu NOA-7000) was used to check the stability of the catalytic activity. Isotopic transient kinetic analysis was performed by switching the flowing gas from 3000ppm 14NO to 3000ppm 15NO diluted in He at 800°C. 0.5g of catalyst samples was employed. The effluent gas from the reactor was continuously monitored by a quadrupole mass spectrometer (PFEFFER OminiStar) for all the isotopic molecules of NO (at m/e =30 and 31), N2 (at 28, 29 and 30), and N2O (at 44, 45 and 46). 2.3 Catalyst characterization The BET surface area of the samples was calculated in the standard manner from nitrogen adsorption isotherm measured volumetrically with a Micromeritics ASAP2010 at liquid nitrogen temperature. The crystal structure of the samples was identified by XRD (Rigaku MiniFlexII) measurements using Cu Kα radiation at 30kV and 15mA. Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) and NO (NO-TPD) was performed using an atmospheric flow system (BELCAT, BEL Japan). Before each CO2-TPD and NO-TPD measurements, the sample was pre-treated in a flow of He at 900°C for 5h and then cooled down to 50°C. CO2 and NO adsorption was performed by passing a gas mixture of 0.5% CO2/He and 0.1% NO/He, respectively, through the sample bed at 50°C for 1h. After the adsorption gas was purged with He to remove physically adsorbed CO2 and NO, TPD measurements were carried out up to 800°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 in flowing He at a flow rate of 30cm3 min−1. A quadrupole mass spectrometer (M-201QA-TDM, Canon Anelva) was used to analyze the desorbed CO2 for CO2-TPD and NO, N2, O2 and N2O for NO-TPD. The diffuse reflectance FT-IR spectra were recorded using a Nicolet Nexus 670 FT-IR spectrometer, accumulating 64 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1. Prior to each experiment, 20mg of a catalyst placed in a diffuse reflectance high temperature cell (Spectra Tech) fitted with CaF2 windows was pre-treated in situ by heating in flowing 10% O2/He at 600°C and then purged in He for 1h, followed by changing to the desired temperature. The background spectrum of the clean surface was measured for spectra correction. The reaction gas containing 1000ppm NO and He as the balance gas was fed to the catalyst at a flow rate of 30cm3 min−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physico-chemical properties and activity of REOs Sesquioxides of trivalent rare earth metals are known to have A-, B-, and C-type crystal structures at temperatures lower than 2000°C [45]. Fig. 1 shows XRD patterns of REOs prepared here. It appears that the crystal structure of REOs is well consistent with the results reported previously: (1) A-type hexagonal; La2O3 and Nd2O3, (2) B-type monoclinic; Sm2O3 and Gd2O3, (3) C-type cubic; Dy2O3 and Y2O3, (4) cubic fluorite; CeO2, Pr6O11 and Tb4O7. Table 1 summarizes the BET surface area of REOs. Although CeO2 and Y2O3 were found to possess relatively high surface area compared with other REOs, no significant difference in the BET surface area was observed. In Table 1 are also summarized the NO decomposition activity of REOs. Although La2O3, CeO2, Pr6O11 and Nd2O3, which are the member of light REOs, showed little NO decomposition activity, Sm2O3, Gd2O3, Tb4O7, Dy2O3 and Y2O3 showed the NO decomposition activity. Among them, Sm2O3 and Y2O3 effectively catalyzed the NO decomposition over the entire temperature range. No relationship between the BET surface area and NO decomposition activity was observed. 3.2 Catalytic performance of Ba-doped REOs 3.2.1 Catalytic activity Fig. 2 shows the activity of Ba-doped REOs for NO decomposition as a function of reaction temperature. From the comparison with Table 1, the NO decomposition activity of REOs was significantly improved by doping Ba. In particular, the promoting effect of Ba was observed for La2O3. Namely, NO conversion to N2 at 800°C was increased from 1.9% on La2O3 to 29.6% on Ba-La2O3. Among the metal oxide based catalysts reported so far, Ba/Y2O3 is one of the active catalysts for NO decomposition reaction [31,35]. As can be seen in Fig. 2, no significant difference in the NO decomposition activity was obtained for Ba-Sm2O3, Ba-Dy2O3 and Ba-Y2O3 catalysts. Among them, Ba-Dy2O3 showed higher NO decomposition activity at the temperatures above 850°C than Ba-Sm2O3 and Ba-Y2O3. The catalytic activity of Ba-doped REOs for NO decomposition was found to decrease in the order of Ba-Dy2O3 ≈Ba-Sm2O3 ≈Ba-Y2O3 >Ba-Nd2O3 >Na-Tb4O7 >Ba-La2O3 > >Ba-Pr6O11 >Ba-CeO2. Sesquioxides of trivalent rare earth metals such as Y2O3 and Dy2O3 seem to be effective support for Ba. 3.2.2 Sate of Ba species as catalytically active sites We have recently reported that the catalytic activity of Ba-Y2O3 for NO decomposition is related to the number of basic sites, which corresponds to highly dispersed Ba species on the catalyst surface [43]. Since the REOs are known to show different surface basicity depending on the radius of rare earth cation [44,45], the dispersion state of Ba species can be expected to be different. CO2-TPD measurements were carried out to examine the surface basicity of REOs. Fig. 3 shows the CO2-TPD profiles of REO itself. It appears that the desorption peaks of CO2 at temperatures between 50 and 600°C were observed, irrespective of REOs. In accordance with previous report [43], La2O3 gave the desorption peak at the highest temperature, around 425°C, suggesting the presence of strong basic sites. It can be roughly said that the desorption peaks located at the highest temperature in all REOs, except CeO2, shifted to the low temperature side with increasing atomic number of the REOs. It is noteworthy that the desorption peak from Dy2O3 and Y2O3 shifted again to higher temperature region. Since Ba-Dy2O3 and Ba-Y2O3 showed high NO decomposition activity (Fig. 2), Ba species may be well dispersed on the surface of Dy2O3 and Y2O3 by the interaction with moderate strength of basic sites. In order to gain information on the dispersion state of Ba species, CO2-TPD profiles of Ba-doped REOs were measured. As can be seen in Fig. 4 , the addition of Ba into REOs caused significant changes in CO2-TPD profiles. Ba-La2O3 (Fig. 4(a)) and Ba-Nd2O3 (Fig. 4(d)) gave a CO2 desorption peak at the temperatures above 750°C, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of BaCO3. The interaction of Ba species with strong basic sites on REOs is suspected to cause the formation of BaCO3. On the other hand, an appearance of new CO2 desorption peaks in the temperature range of 300–600°C was observed for Ba-doped REOs with moderate strength of basic sites. From the comparison of Figs. 3 and 4, the CO2 desorption peak detected for REOs was clearly shifted to higher temperatures by addition of Ba. In addition, an increase in the amount of CO2 desorption at around 300–600°C was also observed. Therefore, the peaks appeared in the temperature range of 300–600°C would be ascribed to the desorption of CO2 adsorbed on Ba species dispersed on REOs. Table 2 summarizes the amount of CO2 desorption at around 300–600°C as well as BET surface area of Ba-doped REOs. Although no linear correlation between the amount of CO2 desorption and BET surface area was observed, Ba-doped REOs with high surface area, except for Ba-La2O3, seems to give large amount of CO2 desorption. Not only the strength of basic sites on REOs but also the surface area of REOs is suspected to be important factor to keep the Ba species in highly dispersion state. We have recently studied the catalytic performance of Ba-doped Y2O3 with different Ba loadings for NO decomposition and found that the amount of Ba species exposed on Y2O3 surface is one of the important factors to determine the NO decomposition activity of Ba-Y2O3 catalyst [43]. In another set of experiment, we have made SEM-EDX analysis to estimate the averaged surface composition of Ba species. However, no good relation between the surface composition of Ba species and the amount of CO2 desorption given in Table 2 was observed. This is probably because large BaCO3 particles, which are not catalytically active sites for NO decomposition [43], deposited on the surface were also detected as Ba species. Therefore, in order to clarify the possibility of Ba species dispersed on REOs as catalytically active sites, the relationship between the amount of desorbed CO2 in the temperature range of 300–600°C and the rate of N2 formation at 800°C was examined, where the both values were normalized by BET surface area. As can be seen in Fig. 5 , the N2 formation rate was found to increase with increasing the amount of CO2 desorption. This clearly suggests that the amount of Ba species exposed on REOs surface is an important factor to determine the NO decomposition activity of Ba-doped REOs catalysts. 3.2.3 Effect of coexisting O2 on the NO decomposition activity of Ba-Dy2O3 The effect of coexisting O2 on the catalytic activity of Ba-Dy2O3, which showed the highest activity among the Ba-doped REOs, was measured, where the concentration of O2 was changed from 0 to 5%. As can be seen in Fig. 6 , the addition of 0.5% O2 into the reaction gas caused a decrease in the NO decomposition activity, and its catalytic activity gradually decreased with increasing O2 concentration up to 5%. This clearly suggests that coexisting O2 inhibits the NO decomposition reaction over Ba-Dy2O3. The negative effect of coexisting O2 has already been reported by many researchers [26,35]. In many cases, the maximum O2 concentration is 10 times higher than that of NO. In the present study, it should be noted that NO conversion is still as high as 32% at 900°C even in the presence of 5% O2, which is 50 times higher than that of NO concentration. 3.3 Mechanistic studies on Ba-La2O3 and Ba-Dy2O3 3.3.1 Adsorption state and reactivity of NO species on Ba-La2O3 and Ba-Dy2O3 The participation of nitrite (NO2 −) species as an intermediate in NO decomposition reaction over alkali metal and alkaline earth metal based catalysts such as Ba/MgO [29,30], K/Co3O4 [46,47] and C-type cubic rare earth oxide-based catalyst [48] has been proposed on the basis of the behavior of adsorption species observed by in situ Raman and/or FT-IR spectroscopy. We have also observed the formation of NO2 − species on Ba-Y2O3 by in situ FT-IR spectroscopy and proposed that highly dispersed Ba species plays an important role for the formation and adsorption of NO2 − species [43]. In order to clarify the possibility of NO2 − species as an intermediate in NO decomposition over Ba-doped REOs, the surface species formed during NO decomposition over Ba-doped REOs were measured using diffuse reflectance FT-IR spectrometer. Here, Ba-Dy2O3 and Ba-La2O3 were chosen as catalyst sample, because the former showed the highest NO decomposition activity (Fig. 2), while the latter showed low activity due to less amounts of highly dispersed Ba species confirmed by CO2-TPD (Fig. 4). As shown in Fig. 7(a), broad but distinct IR band centered at 1175cm−1, which would be ascribed to bridged NO2 − species [49], was observed when 1000ppm NO/He was exposed to Ba-Dy2O3 at 400°C. The IR band decreased with increasing the temperature, but it was still observed at 600°C (Fig. 7(c)). As can be seen in Fig. 7(d), the exposure of NO/He to Ba-La2O3 at 400°C caused an appearance of IR band at 1175cm−1, suggesting no difference in adsorption species formed during NO decomposition over Ba-Dy2O3 and Ba-La2O3. However, the IR band was almost completely disappeared at 500°C (Fig. 7(d)), indicating low thermal stability of NO2 − species adsorbed on Ba-La2O3. Since the NO2 − species has been proposed to serve as an intermediate in NO decomposition as described above, the reactivity of adsorbed NO2 − species was evaluated by NO-TPD measurements. As can be seen in Fig. 8(a), strong NO desorption peak was observed in the desorption profile from Ba-Dy2O3 in the low temperature region around 200°C, suggesting the presence of a large amount of physisorbed NO species. In addition to this peak, an appearance of broad NO desorption peaks in the temperature range of 300–800°C was recognized. In accordance with the results of FT-IR measurements for NO adspecies (Fig. 7), Ba-Dy2O3 can adsorb NOx species at high temperatures at which NO decomposition reaction takes place. On the other hand, in case of Ba-La2O3 (Fig. 8(b)), a weak NO desorption peak was observed at 600°C, indicating low thermal stability of NOx adspecies on Ba-La2O3. This is also well consistent with the results of FT-IR measurements described above. As can be seen in Fig. 8, it is of interest that no formation of N2 was observed in the NO-TPD measurements for Ba-Dy2O3 and Ba-La2O3, whereas O2 was formed along with the desorption of NO at high temperatures. This result suggests that N2 is not formed via the decomposition of adsorbed NOx species. Taking into account the results of FT-IR measurements, the surface reaction of adsorbed NO2 − species with other NOx adspecies is suspected to be a key step for the formation of N2. 3.3.2 Isotopic transient kinetic analysis In order to examine the possibility of the surface reaction of adsorbed NO2 − species with other NOx adspecies, isotopic transient kinetic analysis was made on Ba-Dy2O3 and Ba-La2O3, where the isotopic product responses following the replacement of 14NO/He with 15NO/He in the reaction stream were measured by a quadrupole mass spectrometer at 900°C. Fig. 9 shows the product responses obtained for Ba-Dy2O3. When 14NO/He was exposed to the catalyst, 14N2 and O2 (not shown) were detected as products with no formation of N2O in accordance with the reaction results obtained under the steady-state conditions. The subsequent replacement of 14NO with 15NO caused a decrease in 14N2 production and an increase in 15N2 formation. Since 14NO and 15N2 share the same m/e value, 15N2 formation was estimated by subtracting the 14NO profile, which was separately measured by the 14NO→He switch, from the m/e =30 peaks. It should be noted that the evolution of 14N15N was simultaneously observed. The amount of 14N15N increased gradually with reaction time, reached a maximum and then decreased. This phenomenon clearly indicates that surface-adsorbed species act as reaction intermediates in the formation of N2 in NO decomposition. Tsujimoto et al. [48] also proposed that the NO decomposition over C-type cubic (Y0.69Tb0.30Ba0.01)2O2.99+δ proceeds by the reaction of adsorbed NOx species with gas-phase NO. They observed the formation of nitrosyl (NO−) species at 800°C by in situ FT-IR spectroscopy, and concluded the participation of NO− species as reaction intermediate. Therefore, taking into account the results of FT-IR and NO-TPD described above (Figs. 7 and 8), it is logical to conclude that the surface reaction of adsorbed NO2 − species with other NOx adspecies is suspected to be a key step for the formation of N2 over Ba-Dy2O3. Almost the same isotopic product responses were observed for Ba-La2O3. As can be seen in Fig. 10 , very small amount of 14N15N was formed on Ba-La2O3 by the replacement of 14NO/He with 15NO/He at 900°C, suggesting the participation of adsorbed NO2 − species as an intermediate. The NO decomposition reaction over Ba-Dy2O3 and Ba-La2O3 was suspected to proceed via the same reaction pathway. However, the formation and reaction behavior of adsorbed NO2 − species over Ba-Dy2O3 and Ba-La2O3 seems to be quite different. The response of 14NO and 15NO levels over Ba-Dy2O3 by the replacement of 14NO/He with 15NO/He is very slow (Fig. 9), whereas that over Ba-La2O3 is very fast (Fig. 10). These results suggest that the formation of adsorbed NO2 − species over Ba-Dy2O3 is fast enough for NO decomposition to take place, while that over Ba-La2O3 is a slow reaction step. Taking into account the fact that the N2 formation rate on Ba-doped REOs was increased with increasing the amount of Ba species exposed on REOs surface (Fig. 5), highly dispersed Ba species plays an important role for the formation, adsorption, stabilization and subsequent reaction of NO2 − species as a reaction intermediate in NO decomposition, leading to high NO decomposition activity. 4 Conclusions Although all the rare earth oxides tested here showed NO decomposition activity, Sm2O3 and Y2O3 were found to effectively catalyze the NO decomposition over the entire temperature range. However, the addition of Ba into rare earth oxide caused a significant promotion of NO decomposition reaction. Among the catalysts tested here, Ba-Dy2O3, Ba-Sm2O3 and Ba-Y2O3 were highly active catalysts for NO decomposition. CO2-TPD measurements of Ba-doped rare earth oxides revealed that the dispersion state of Ba species is strongly dependent on rare earth oxides as a support. Ba species supported on rare earth oxides with moderate strength of basic sites such as Dy2O3, Sm2O3 and Y2O3 is highly dispersed on the surface, while that on La2O3 and Nd2O3 with relatively strong basic sites is present as BaCO3. The N2 formation rate over Ba-doped rare earth oxides was increased with increasing the amount of Ba species exposed on the surface of rare earth oxides, suggesting that highly dispersed Ba species acts as catalytically active sites for NO decomposition. The main surface species formed during NO decomposition reaction detectable by IR was nitrite (NO2 −) species, the amount of which decreased with increasing temperature. However, NO-TPD measurements indicated that N2 is not formed via the decomposition of adsorbed NOx species. Isotopic transient kinetic analysis performed following the 14NO→ 15NO switch revealed the participation of surface-adsorbed species to be an intermediate in NO decomposition. The surface reaction of adsorbed NO2 − species with other NOx adspecies was proposed to be a key step for the formation of N2 over Ba-doped rare earth oxides. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic performance of Ba-doped rare earth oxides prepared by a co-precipitation method for the direct decomposition of NO was investigated. Although rare earth oxide catalyzed NO decomposition reaction, their activities were significantly increased by addition of Ba. Ba-Dy2O3, Ba-Sm2O3 and Ba-Y2O3 showed relatively high catalytic activity. CO2-TPD measurements of Ba-doped rare earth oxides revealed that Ba species supported on rare earth oxides with moderate strength of basic sites, such as Dy2O3, Sm2O3 and Y2O3, can be highly dispersed on the surface of support oxide, suggesting that highly dispersed Ba species acts as catalytically active sites for NO decomposition. Although the formation of nitrite (NO2 −) species during NO decomposition reaction over Ba-Dy2O3 and Ba-La2O3 was confirmed by in situ FT-IR spectroscopy, NO-TPD measurements suggested that the formation of N2 does not occur by the decomposition of adsorbed NOx species. Isotopic transient kinetic analysis performed using 14NO and 15NO revealed that the surface reaction of adsorbed species, probably NO2 −, as an intermediate with other NOx adspecies is a key step for the formation of N2. Highly dispersed Ba species was considered to play an important role for the formation, adsorption, stabilization and subsequent reaction of NO2 − species in NO decomposition.
coredata.dc:title: Direct decomposition of NO on Ba catalysts supported on rare earth oxides
